reason.tex: %text Nothing in the problem statement is written without a reason. Which is why it is important to understand every bit of it $A = \Q\times\Q \implies A$ is the \underline\text{Cartesian product} of two $\Q$ sets Hence, $A$ will be made up of elements like $\left(x,y \right)$ where both $x,y\in\Q$ Had $A = \Q\times\Q\times\Q$, then $A$ would have been composed of elements like $\left(x,y,z \right)$ where $x,y,z\in\Q$. See the pattern? And therefore, in this question \[ \quad \left(a,b \right), \left(c,d \right)\in A\text{ but } a,b,c,d\in\Q \] %

%text If $X = (x,y) = (a,b)^{-1}$, then % \begin{align}
(a,b) * (x,y) &= I = (1,0) \\ \implies \left(ax, b + ay \right) &= (1,0) \\ \text{or } ax &= 1 \text{ and } b + ay = 0 \\[-10pt] \therefore x &= \frac{1}{a} \text{ and } y = \frac{-b}{a} \end{align} %text Hence, the \underline\text{inverse element} of $(a,b)$ is \[\qquad X = \left(\dfrac{1}{a},-\dfrac{b}{a} \right), a \neq 0\] Notice that any element with $a=0$, like $(0,3)$, has \underline\text{no inverse element}%
